channel.title: NYT > World News
channel.copyright: Copyright 2022 The New York Times Company

item.title: Myanmar Is Mired in Conflict and Chaos a Year After a Coup
item.description: Daily protests, once loud and colorful, have been replaced by an eerie quiet. To mark the anniversary of the military takeover, protest leaders have called for a “silent strike.”
item.dc:creator: Richard C. Paddock and The New York Times
item.category: Coups D'Etat and Attempted Coups D'Etat
item.media:description: A demonstrator making a three-finger protest symbol during a demonstration in Yangon, Myanmar, in February last year.

item.title: In Kazakh Uprising, Reports of Widespread Abuses by Security Forces
item.description: Through crowdsourcing, rights groups say they are documenting a campaign of beatings and torture.
item.dc:creator: Valerie Hopkins
item.category: Human Rights and Human Rights Violations
item.media:credit: Sergey Ponomarev for The New York Times
item.media:description: Asset Abishev, a Kazakh political activist, 11 days after he was released from police custody in January.

item.title: Ahead of Winter Olympics, Beijing Moves to Quash Dissent
item.description: As athletes begin to arrive in China for the Olympics, the authorities are rounding up activists and shutting down social media accounts.
item.dc:creator: Paul Mozur, Steven Lee Myers and John Liu
item.media:description: Athletes, journalists and team officials arriving in Beijing on Saturday.

item.title: Migrant Worker’s Tale of Inequality Grips China, Then Is Erased
item.description: A man with Covid revealed a parallel universe to well-off Chinese and became a symbol of inequality. The government found him inconvenient to its narrative.
item.dc:creator: Li Yuan

item.title: Video of Mentally Ill Woman Chained in Shack Stirs Anger in China
item.description: Public discussion of mental illness has grown in recent years, but in rural areas, resources and acceptance are still limited.
item.dc:creator: Vivian Wang and Joy Dong

item.title: #MeToo Scandal at a Dutch TV Show Spurs a Sexual Assault Reckoning
item.description: The allegations against four men appearing on the Dutch version of “The Voice” talent show have helped to prompt a surge in reports of sexual assaults, victims’ groups say.
item.dc:creator: Claire Moses
item.media:description: Women protesting against gender violence in Amsterdam in 2019.

item.title: Covid’s New Divide: Risk Takers vs. the Risk Averse
item.description: In Italy, with its high vaccination rate, the social schism revolves less around who’s gotten a shot, and more around lifestyles and comfort levels of living with the coronavirus.
item.dc:creator: Jason Horowitz
item.media:description: A bus this month in Rome. In Italy, more than 80 percent of the population, including children, has had two doses of a coronavirus vaccine.

item.title: Angry US-Russia Exchange at UN Punctuates Deepening Ukraine Rift
item.description: With vitriolic accusations that echoed the Cold War era, the United States and Russia sparred in a bitter debate over the Ukraine crisis in a Security Council meeting watched by the world on Monday.
item.dc:creator: Rick Gladstone and Maria Varenikova
item.media:description: Russia and the United States clashed at a U.N. Security Council meeting on Monday over a massive Russian military buildup on the Ukrainian border.

item.title: For Some of Ukraine’s Neighbors, ‘Defend Europe’ Has Another Meaning
item.description: For the populist leaders of Poland and Hungary, Russia’s saber-rattling on the border with Ukraine takes a back seat to domestic politics and issues like immigration.
item.dc:creator: Andrew Higgins
item.media:credit: Oscar Del Pozo/Agence France-Presse — Getty Images
item.media:description: Prime Minister Viktor Orban of Hungary on Saturday at a meeting of populist leaders in Madrid.

item.title: Sue Gray's Report on Parties Deepens Crisis for Boris Johnson
item.description: A long-awaited assessment on whether Downing Street flouted lockdown rules declared that there were “failures of leadership and judgment’’ by Mr. Johnson’s government.
item.dc:creator: Mark Landler and Stephen Castle
item.media:description: Prime Minister Boris Johnson of Britain outside 10 Downing Street on Monday.

item.title: Teenage Inmates Found Among the 500 Dead in Syria Prison Attack
item.description: The bodies of at least two boys were found on a street behind the prison — the first confirmed deaths among up to 700 teenagers who had been detained there because they were the children of ISIS fighters.
item.dc:creator: Jane Arraf and Sangar Khaleel
item.category: Islamic State in Iraq and Syria (ISIS)
item.media:credit: Diego Ibarra Sanchez for The New York Times
item.media:description: A woman sat with her child on the rubble of her house in Hasaka, Syria, on Sunday. The home was destroyed in operations by the Syrian Democratic Forces aimed at capturing ISIS militants.

item.title: Trudeau Condemns 'Freedom Convoy' Trucker Protest in Ottawa
item.description: The Canadian prime minister, who tested positive for Covid-19, railed against protesters for violence, racism and spreading misinformation.
item.dc:creator: Dan Bilefsky and Vjosa Isai
item.media:description: Prime Minister Justin Trudeau on Monday. Mr. Trudeau tested positive for the coronavirus after an exposure last week.

item.title: Cyprus Overturns Conviction of Woman Who Accused Israelis of Rape
item.description: More than two years after a British woman was convicted of fabricating claims, Cyprus’s top court reversed the decision and said that she had not received a fair trial.
item.dc:creator: Jenny Gross and Isabel Kershner
item.media:description: Protesters in support of a British woman who had been convicted of fabricating claims, outside of Cyprus's Supreme Court in Nicosia on Monday.

item.title: Brian Houston Steps Down as Leader of Hillsong, Australian Megachurch
item.description: Brian Houston, who was the leader of Hillsong, is accused of concealing past abuse by his father, who later died and was never charged.
item.dc:creator: Yan Zhuang
item.media:description: Brian Houston said of the police’s charges, “These allegations came as a shock to me, and it is my intention to vigorously defend them.”

item.title: Your Tuesday Briefing
item.description: A diplomatic showdown at the U.N.
item.dc:creator: Natasha Frost
item.media:description: Russia called the public meeting on the Ukraine crisis an example of “megaphone diplomacy,” while the U.S. criticized Russia, saying, “Imagine how uncomfortable you would be if you had 100,000 troops sitting at your border.”

item.title: U.S. and Allies Close to Reviving Nuclear Deal With Iran, Officials Say
item.description: A return to a 2015 accord is on the table, but the next decisions are up to the new government in Tehran, the Biden administration says.
item.dc:creator: David E. Sanger, Lara Jakes and Farnaz Fassihi
item.media:description: Restoring the deal from 2015 would mean all limits on the production of nuclear material would still expire in 2030, at which point Iran would be free to resume the kind of fuel production it has underway now.

item.title: White House Ready With Sanctions on Putin's Inner Circle
item.description: The Biden administration said the penalties would exceed any levied recently against Russia. It is whether the list of targets includes Vladimir V. Putin himself.
item.dc:creator: David E. Sanger
item.media:credit: Tom Brenner for The New York Times

item.title: Biden Designates Qatar as a Major Non-NATO Ally
item.description: The move clears the way for greater security cooperation and investment at a time when President Biden is seeking help boosting natural gas supplies in Europe.
item.dc:creator: Michael D. Shear
item.media:credit: Tom Brenner for The New York Times
item.media:description: Sheikh Tamim bin Hamad al-Thani, the emir of Qatar, and President Biden met at the White House on Monday.

item.title: Your Tuesday Briefing: A Diplomatic Clash Over Ukraine
item.description: Russians said the U.S. was fanning flames.
item.dc:creator: Melina Delkic
item.media:description: Russia and the United States clashed at a U.N. Security Council meeting on Monday.

item.title: Putin and Macron Talk Again on Ukraine and De-Escalation
item.description: The two leaders discussed Ukraine and Russia’s demand for “security guarantees” that would include a legally binding halt on NATO expansion to the east.
item.dc:creator: Anton Troianovski and Aurelien Breeden
item.media:description: President Emmanuel Macron of France speaking in 2020 with President Vladimir V. Putin of Russia over a video call.

item.title: Javid Calls For Review of England’s Vaccine Mandate for Health Workers
item.description: A deadline of April 1, imposed in the fall when Delta was raging, may not be the right policy for Omicron, the health secretary, Sajid Javid, said on Monday.
item.dc:creator: Cora Engelbrecht
item.media:description: NHS workers in England will not be required to be vaccinated against Covid-19, the British health minister told Parliament on Monday.

item.title: What a Disconnect From Swift Would Mean for Russia
item.description: A Belgian financial messaging service is once again at the center of an international sanctions fight.
item.dc:creator: Alan Rappeport
item.category: SWIFT(Society for Worldwide Interbank Financial Telecommunication)
item.media:credit: Brendan Hoffman for The New York Times
item.media:description: Members of the Ukrainian Army at a training site in Volnovakha, Ukraine. The United States could levy sanctions against Russia if it invades Ukraine.

item.title: Justin Trudeau Tests Positive for Covid
item.description: Mr. Trudeau, who has been isolating since Thursday after a coronavirus exposure, confirmed his positive test result on Monday morning.
item.dc:creator: Vjosa Isai
item.media:description: Justin Trudeau tested positive for the coronavirus after being exposed to the virus last week.

item.title: Omicron Surge in Asia Restricts Travel for Lunar New Year
item.description: The Omicron variant has dampened the plans of tens of millions of people across several Asian countries to travel for the holiday.
item.dc:creator: Jin Yu Young
item.media:description: Passengers at the domestic terminal of Gimpo Airport in Seoul, South Korea, on Saturday, ahead of the Lunar New Year holiday.

item.title: The Power of Boosters
item.description: New C.D.C. data shows their effectiveness.
item.dc:creator: David Leonhardt
item.media:credit: Emily Elconin for The New York Times
item.media:description: Nurses preparing vaccines in Rochester Hills, Mich.

item.title: Women Under Financial Stress Faced Abuse During Pandemic, Researchers Find
item.description: Women who experienced financial hardship as a result of the pandemic were also more likely to be abused by their partners, according to an Australian study.
item.dc:creator: Livia Albeck-Ripka
item.media:description: Sydney, Australia, during a lockdown last year. Research suggests that many women have been negatively affected by the pandemic, and money worries and domestic abuse are often connected.

item.title: A coronavirus infection illuminates a migrant worker’s tale of inequality in China.
item.dc:creator: Li Yuan
item.media:description: The neighborhood of Shigezhuang in Chaoyang District, Beijing, in 2016. The migrant worker, surnamed “Yue,” lived in the area, renting a room for about $100 a month.

item.title: Liquor stores prepare for battle as New York revisits to-go drinks from the early pandemic days.
item.dc:creator: Luis Ferré-Sadurní
item.media:credit: David Rothenberg for The New York Times
item.media:description: Liquor stores in New York are at odds with the restaurant industry as a law to permanently allow to-go cocktails will be considered during the current state legislative session.

item.title: Easy Covid entry rules help drive tourism to the Dominican Republic.
item.dc:creator: Heather Murphy
item.media:description: Tourists have flocked to the Dominican Republic over the last year, but the Caribbean nation has managed to keep the number of Covid cases low.

item.title: As Waste Rises in Senegal, So Does Plastic Recycling
item.description: Plagued by plastic pollution, Senegal wants to replace pickers at the garbage dump with a formal recycling system that takes advantage of the new market for plastics.
item.dc:creator: Ruth Maclean and Finbarr O’Reilly
item.media:description: Waste pickers, scrubbers, choppers and haulers at the dump constitute an informal economy that supports thousands of families.

item.title: Your Monday Briefing
item.description: Proposed sanctions against Russia.
item.dc:creator: Natasha Frost
item.media:description: The pandemic has given Xi Jinping, China’s top leader, a powerful case for deepening the Communist Party’s reach into the lives of 1.4 billion residents.

item.title: Portugal’s Socialists Win an Outright Majority in Parliamentary Election
item.description: Because of a strong performance in the snap elections, the governing party will not have to form a coalition in the fractious Parliament.
item.dc:creator: Nicholas Casey
item.media:description: Supporters of Portugal’s Socialist Party after the polls closed in Lisbon on Sunday.

item.title: Your Monday Briefing: U.S. Floats Russian Sanctions
item.description: Also, the defeat of ISIS fighters in Syria and China’s pandemic surveillance state.
item.dc:creator: Amelia Nierenberg
item.category: Far East, South and Southeast Asia and Pacific Areas
Islamic State in Iraq and Syria (ISIS)
item.media:description: Sanctions could be viewed as punishing the Russian people — a perception that might fuel President Vladimir V. Putin’s narrative that his country is being persecuted by the West.

item.title: The Hard-Line Russian Advisers Who Have Putin’s Ear
item.description: Three reactionary security officials dedicated to “traditional values” and restoring Soviet glory will figure prominently in the decision whether to invade Ukraine.
item.dc:creator: Anton Troianovski
item.media:credit: Sergey Ponomarev for The New York Times
item.media:description: A winter market this week in Moscow. Russia says it has no plans to invade Ukraine, but no one on either side of the border really knows what President Vladimir V. Putin of Russia will decide.

item.title: Obscure but Crucial Commodity Fuels Geopolitical Tussle in Eastern Europe
item.description: Lithuanian efforts to stop potash, a key fertilizer ingredient, from Belarus from crossing its territory to punish the country’s authoritarian leader may play into Russia’s hands.
item.dc:creator: Andrew Higgins
item.media:credit: Andrej Vasilenko for The New York Times
item.media:description: A freight train transporting potash from Belarus at the Klaipeda port in Lithuania. Lithuania plans to halt imports of the fertilizer, in what it hopes will be a blow to the Belarusian economy.

item.title: Britain Toughens Stance on Russia, as Russia Presses NATO for Assurances
item.description: Britain moved to broaden the range of sanctions available if Russia invades Ukraine, as Moscow sent an “urgent demand” to NATO to clarify its stance.
item.dc:creator: Anna Schaverien
item.media:credit: Brendan Hoffman for The New York Times
item.media:description: Ukrainian troops training on Thursday in Volnovakha, in eastern Ukraine.

item.title: England Extends Covid Vaccinations to Vulnerable Children Ages 5 to 11
item.description: Around half a million children in England will become eligible for a first dose of a coronavirus shot on Monday.
item.dc:creator: Anna Schaverien
item.media:description: A dose of the Pfizer-BioNTech coronavirus vaccine being prepared in London last month.

item.title: U.S. Allies Retake Control of Prison in Syria, Subduing ISIS Fighters
item.description: The fighting was the most intense urban warfare involving American troops in Iraq and Syria since the fall of the Islamic State.
item.dc:creator: Jane Arraf and Sangar Khaleel
item.category: United States Defense and Military Forces
Islamic State in Iraq and Syria (ISIS)
item.media:credit: Diego Ibarra Sanchez for The New York Times
item.media:description: Fighting spilled into a residential area of Hasaka, Syria, on Saturday near where Kurdish forces were trying to subdue the last ISIS fighters barricaded in a prison.

item.title: China's Covid-Era Controls May Outlast the Coronavirus
item.description: The country has instituted a wide range of high-tech controls on society as part of a mostly successful effort to stop the virus. The consequences may endure.
item.dc:creator: Chris Buckley, Vivian Wang and Keith Bradsher
item.category: Human Rights and Human Rights Violations
item.media:description: The pandemic has given Xi Jinping, China’s top leader, a powerful case for deepening the Communist Party’s reach into the lives of 1.4 billion residents.

item.title: North Korea’s Latest Missile Test Appears to Be Its Boldest in Years
item.description: Flight data indicates that the launch on Sunday was the North’s most powerful since 2017. South Korean analysts expect further escalations from Kim Jong-un.
item.dc:creator: Choe Sang-Hun
item.media:description: Watching coverage of North Korea’s latest missile launch in Seoul on Sunday.

item.title: Putin Has Long Tried to Balance Europe. Now He’s Working to Reset It.
item.description: After years of trying to diplomatically divide and conquer, the Russian leader has seemingly decided to antagonize Europe as a whole in the current Ukraine crisis.
item.dc:creator: Max Fisher
item.media:description: Carrying a howitzer shell on Wednesday during Russian Army drills in the region bordering Ukraine.

item.title: U.S. Woman Accused of Prominent Role in Islamic State
item.description: Prosecutors said Allison Fluke-Ekren, a former teacher from Kansas, provided military training to women and young girls in Syria.
item.dc:creator: Adam Goldman
item.category: Islamic State in Iraq and Syria (ISIS)
item.media:description: The F.B.I. flew Allison Fluke-Ekren to Virginia on Friday to face prosecution. She has been charged with providing material support to a terrorist organization.

item.title: U.S. Sanctions Aimed at Russia Could Take a Wide Toll
item.description: The boldest measures that President Biden is threatening to deter an invasion of Ukraine could roil the entire Russian economy — but also those of other nations.
item.dc:creator: Michael Crowley and Edward Wong
item.media:description: Sanctions could be viewed as punishing the Russian people — a perception that might fuel President Vladimir V. Putin’s narrative that his country is being persecuted by the West.

item.title: How France's Macron Is Approaching the Ukraine Situation
item.description: The French president, determined to engage with Russia, wants to shape a new European security order from crisis — and win the April election.
item.dc:creator: Roger Cohen
item.media:description: President Emmanuel Macron of France with President Vladimir V. Putin of Russia at his Fort of Brégançon presidential summer residence in 2019.

item.title: Italian Lawmakers Re-Elect Sergio Mattarella as President, Preserving Status Quo
item.description: Mr. Mattarella has presided over a chaotic seven years in which the country swung wildly from the left to the right, acting as the guardrails of Italy’s democracy.
item.dc:creator: Jason Horowitz
item.media:description: President Sergio Mattarella of Italy was elected to another term on Saturday.

item.title: 50 Years On, Bloody Sunday’s Wounds Are Still Felt
item.description: A half-century after the killings in Northern Ireland, symbols of division and hostility still hold their potency.
item.dc:creator: Alan Cowell

item.title: Is It OK to Watch the Winter Games? A Former Olympian Weighs In.
item.description: This year’s Winter Olympics come in the midst of widespread human rights abuses in China and a low point in Canada’s relations with the country.
item.dc:creator: Ian Austen
item.media:description: Xi Jinping, the leader of China, planned the Winter Olympics as a showcase of the country under his rule.

item.title: ‘My Soul Is Crying’: Ukrainians Remember a Deadly Rocket Attack
item.description: Residents in Mariupol, a Ukrainian frontline city rocked by shelling in 2015, mourn the dead as they brace for a potential Russian escalation.
item.dc:creator: Yousur Al-Hlou, Brent McDonald, Andriy Dubchak and Dmitriy Khavin

item.title: ISIS Siege of Syria Prison Proves It's Still a Threat
item.description: The Islamic State may no longer be able to control territory, but it has shown in Syria and Iraq that it can still pull off opportunistic military operations.
item.dc:creator: Ben Hubbard
item.category: United States Defense and Military Forces
Islamic State in Iraq and Syria (ISIS)
item.media:credit: Diego Ibarra Sanchez for The New York Times
item.media:description: Kurdish militia fighters warming themselves on Friday near a prison in Hasaka, Syria, that Islamic State fighters had attacked.

item.title: In Canada, ‘Freedom Convoy’ Protesting Vaccine Mandates Nears Capital
item.description: The “Freedom Convoy” had driven across Canada to reach the capital. The demonstrations on Saturday were raucous but largely peaceful.
item.dc:creator: Ian Austen and Vjosa Isai
item.media:credit: Nasuna Stuart-Ulin for The New York Times
item.media:description: Protesters around Parliament Hill in downtown Ottawa on Saturday.

item.title: As Russian Troops Mass in Belarus, a Ukraine Border Is Largely Undefended
item.description: From the border, it’s a fast 140 miles down a newly paved highway to Kyiv, the Ukrainian capital, but only a few troops stand guard.
item.dc:creator: Michael Schwirtz
item.media:credit: Brendan Hoffman for The New York Times
item.media:description: The E-95 highway from Chernihiv toward Kyiv.

item.title: India’s Militarized Nagaland Calls for End to Army Impunity
item.description: A deadly mistaken ambush by soldiers seeking rebels in the country’s northeast has renewed attention on a special powers act that residents say perpetuates fear and harassment.
item.dc:creator: Hari Kumar and Mujib Mashal
item.media:credit: Saumya Khandelwal for The New York Times
item.media:description: Charred vehicles, torched during protests, at the site where Indian Army Special Forces shot and killed a group of ethnic Naga villagers near Oting, India, in December.

item.title: U.S. Blocks $130 Million in Aid for Egypt Over Rights Abuses
item.description: The Middle Eastern ally continues to buy billions of dollars worth of military equipment from the United States.
item.dc:creator: Lara Jakes and Mona El-Naggar
item.category: Human Rights and Human Rights Violations
item.media:description: Secretary of State Antony J. Blinken and Foreign Minister Sameh Shoukry of Egypt spoke by phone on Thursday.

item.title: White House Warnings Over Russia Strain Ukraine-U.S. Partnership
item.description: While Ukraine’s president complained about “acute and burning” warnings from Washington, the Pentagon issued a dire new appraisal asserting Russia has amassed enough troops to invade his entire country.
item.dc:creator: Michael Schwirtz and Andrew E. Kramer
item.media:credit: Brendan Hoffman for The New York Times
item.media:description: Ukrainian soldiers training in the Volnovakha district in eastern Ukraine.

item.title: Canadian Truck Convoys Head to Ottawa to Protest Vaccine Mandate
item.description: Truckers from across the country aim to converge at on Saturday outside of Parliament to protest federal vaccination mandates.
item.dc:creator: Vjosa Isai
item.media:description: Truckers drove through Toronto on Thursday on their way to Ottawa, the Canadian capital, to protest Covid vaccination requirements for those who cross the U.S. border.

item.title: U.S. Says Russian Gas Line to Germany Will Be Blocked If War Comes
item.description: The pipeline to Germany would expand Russia’s capacity to sell gas to Europe, which is already highly dependent on Russian energy.
item.dc:creator: Michael Crowley
item.media:description: A Russian pipe-laying ship, working on construction of the Nord Stream 2, moored at the Mukran Port on the island of Ruegen, Germany, in 2020.
